org.chronos.chronodb.api

Interface ChronoDBTransaction

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    StandardChronoDBTransaction, ThreadSafeChronoDBTransaction

    public interface ChronoDBTransaction
    A ChronoDBTransaction encapsulates a set of queries and/or change operations on a ChronoDB.

    Instances of this interface are produced by a TransactionSource. API users should make use of the methods of ChronoDB, which implements TransactionSource.

    Instances of this class are in general not guaranteed to be thread-safe, and should not be shared among threads.

    Note that opening a ChronoTransaction does not imply any further obligations. In particular, ChronoTransactions do not have to be closed or terminated in any way.

    Changes made to the transaction will not be persisted immediately. They will be kept in-memory until commit() is invoked. Calling rollback() will clear this in-memory cache.

    Users may continue to use a ChronoDBTransaction after calling commit() or rollback() on it. It will behave as if it had been newly instantiated.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static interface  ChronoDBTransaction.Configuration
      This interface represents the configuration of a single transaction.

    • Method Detail

      • getTimestamp

        long getTimestamp()
        Returns the timestamp on which this transaction operates.
        Returns:
        The timestamp, which is always a number greater than (or equal to) zero.

      • getBranchName

        java.lang.String getBranchName()
        Returns an identifier for the branch on which this transaction operates.
        Returns:
        The branch identifier

      • get

        <T> T get(java.lang.String key)
   throws ValueTypeMismatchException
        Returns the value of the given key in the default keyspace, at the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         // note the automatic cast to the expected type
 String value = tx.get("Hello");
        Parameters:
        key - The key to get the value for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The value associated with the given key, cast to the given generic argument. Returns null if there is no value for the given key.
        Throws:
        ValueTypeMismatchException - Thrown if the stored value cannot be cast to the expected type argument.

      • get

        <T> T get(java.lang.String keyspaceName,
          java.lang.String key)
   throws ValueTypeMismatchException,
          UnknownKeyspaceException
        Returns the value of the given key in the given keyspace, at the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         // note the automatic cast to the expected type
 String value = tx.get("MyKeyspace", "Hello");
        Parameters:
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to search in. Must not be null.
        key - The key to get the value for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The value associated with the given key, cast to the given generic argument. Returns null if there is no value for the given key.
        Throws:
        ValueTypeMismatchException - Thrown if the stored value cannot be cast to the expected type argument.
        UnknownKeyspaceException - Thrown if the specified keyspace name does not refer to an existing keyspace.

      • exists

        boolean exists(java.lang.String key)
        Checks if there is a value for the given key in the default keyspace, at the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         boolean keyExists = tx.exists("MyKey")
        Parameters:
        key - The key to check the existence of a value for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if there is a value for the given key, otherwise false.

      • exists

        boolean exists(java.lang.String keyspaceName,
               java.lang.String key)
        Checks if there is a value for the given key in the given keyspace, at the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         boolean keyExists = tx.exists("MyKeyspace", "MyKey")
        Parameters:
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to search in. Must not be null.
        key - The key to check the existence of a value for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        true if there is a value for the given key, otherwise false.

      • keySet

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> keySet()
        Returns the set of all keys present in the default keyspace at the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         for (String key : tx.keySet()) {
        tx.exists(key); // is always true
 }
        Returns:
        The key set. May be empty, but never null.

      • keySet

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> keySet(java.lang.String keyspaceName)
        Returns the set of all keys present in the given keyspace at the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         for (String key : tx.keySet("MyKeyspace")) {
        tx.exists(key); // is always true
 }
        Parameters:
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to scan. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The key set. May be empty, but never null.

      • history

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> history(java.lang.String key)
        Returns the timestamps in the past at which the value for the given key has changed in the default keyspace, up to the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         Iterator<Long> iterator = tx.history("MyKey");
 while (iterator.hasNext()) {
        long timestamp = iterator.next();
        Object pastValue = chronoDB.tx(timestamp).get("MyKey");
        String msg = "At timestamp " + timestamp + ", the value of 'MyKey' was changed to '" + pastValue + "'";
        System.out.println(msg);
 }
        Parameters:
        key - The key to get the history for. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        An iterator over the history timestamps. May be empty, but never null. The exact ordering of the returned keys is up to the implementation. Implementations should try to return the timestamps in descending order (highest first).

      • history

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> history(java.lang.String keyspaceName,
                                           java.lang.String key)
        Returns the timestamps in the past at which the value for the given key has changed in the given keyspace, up to the timestamp of this transaction.

        Usage example: 

         Iterator<Long> iterator = tx.history("MyKeyspace", "MyKey");
 while (iterator.hasNext()) {
        long timestamp = iterator.next();
        Object pastValue = chronoDB.tx(timestamp).get("MyKey");
        String msg = "At timestamp " + timestamp + ", the value of 'MyKey' was changed to '" + pastValue + "'";
        System.out.println(msg);
 }
        Parameters:
        key - The key to get the history for. Must not be null.
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to scan. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        An iterator over the history timestamps. May be empty, but never null. The exact ordering of the returned keys is up to the implementation. Implementations should try to return the timestamps in descending order (highest first).

      • getModificationsInKeyspaceBetween

        java.util.Iterator<TemporalKey> getModificationsInKeyspaceBetween(java.lang.String keyspace,
                                                                  long timestampLowerBound,
                                                                  long timestampUpperBound)
        Returns an iterator over the modified keys in the given timestamp range.

        Please note that timestampLowerBound and timestampUpperBound must not be larger than the timestamp of this transaction, i.e. you can only look for timestamp ranges in the past with this method.

        Parameters:
        keyspace - The keyspace to look for changes in. Must not be null. For non-existing keyspaces, the resulting iterator will be empty.
        timestampLowerBound - The lower bound on the time range to look for. Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to timestampUpperBound. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        timestampUpperBound - The upper bound on the time range to look for. Must not be negative. Must be greater than or equal to timestampLowerBound. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        Returns:
        An iterator containing the TemporalKeys that reflect the modifications. May be empty, but never null.

      • getCommitMetadata

        java.lang.Object getCommitMetadata(long commitTimestamp)
        Returns the metadata object stored alongside the commit at the given timestamp.

        It is important that the given timestamp matches the commit timestamp exactly. Commit timestamps can be retrieved for example via getModificationsInKeyspaceBetween(String, long, long).

        Parameters:
        commitTimestamp - The commit timestamp to get the metadata object for. Must match the commit timestamp exactly. Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction (i.e. must be in the past).
        Returns:
        The object stored alongside that commit. Will be null for all timestamps that are not associated with a commit. May also be null in cases where no metadata object was given for the commit by the user.

      • getCommitTimestampsBetween

        default java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> getCommitTimestampsBetween(long from,
                                                                      long to)
        Returns an iterator over all timestamps where commits have occurred, bounded between from and to, in descending order.

        If the from value is greater than the to value, this method always returns an empty iterator.

        Parameters:
        from - The lower bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The upper bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        Returns:
        The iterator over the commit timestamps in the given time range, in descending order. May be empty, but never null.

      • getCommitTimestampsBetween

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> getCommitTimestampsBetween(long from,
                                                              long to,
                                                              Order order)
        Returns an iterator over all timestamps where commits have occurred, bounded between from and to.

        If the from value is greater than the to value, this method always returns an empty iterator.

        Parameters:
        from - The lower bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The upper bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        order - The order of the returned timestamps. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The iterator over the commit timestamps in the given time range. May be empty, but never null.

      • getCommitMetadataBetween

        default java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> getCommitMetadataBetween(long from,
                                                                                                          long to)
        Returns an iterator over the entries of commit timestamp and associated metadata, bounded between from and to, in descending order.

        If the from value is greater than the to value, this method always returns an empty iterator.

        Please keep in mind that some commits may not have any metadata attached. In this case, the value component of the Map.Entry will be set to null.

        Parameters:
        from - The lower bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The upper bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        Returns:
        An iterator over the commits in the given time range in descending order. The contained entries have the timestamp as the key component and the associated metadata as their value component (which may be null). May be empty, but never null.

      • getCommitMetadataBetween

        java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> getCommitMetadataBetween(long from,
                                                                                                  long to,
                                                                                                  Order order)
        Returns an iterator over the entries of commit timestamp and associated metadata, bounded between from and to.

        If the from value is greater than the to value, this method always returns an empty iterator.

        Please keep in mind that some commits may not have any metadata attached. In this case, the value component of the Map.Entry will be set to null.

        Parameters:
        from - The lower bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The upper bound of the time range to look for commits in (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        order - The order of the returned commits. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        An iterator over the commits in the given time range. The contained entries have the timestamp as the key component and the associated metadata as their value component (which may be null). May be empty, but never null.

      • getCommitTimestampsPaged

        java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Long> getCommitTimestampsPaged(long minTimestamp,
                                                            long maxTimestamp,
                                                            int pageSize,
                                                            int pageIndex,
                                                            Order order)
        Returns an iterator over commit timestamps in a paged fashion.

        For example, calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(10000, 100, 0, Order.DESCENDING) will give the latest 100 commit timestamps that have occurred before timestamp 10000. Calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(123456, 200, 2, Order.DESCENDING will return 200 commit timestamps, skipping the 400 latest commit timestamps, which are smaller than 123456.

        Parameters:
        minTimestamp - The minimum timestamp to consider (inclusive). All lower timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        maxTimestamp - The highest timestamp to consider (inclusive). All higher timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        pageSize - The size of the page, i.e. the maximum number of elements allowed to be contained in the resulting iterator. Must be greater than zero.
        pageIndex - The index of the page to retrieve. Must not be negative.
        order - The desired ordering for the commit timestamps
        Returns:
        An iterator that contains the commit timestamps for the requested page. Never null, may be empty. If the requested page does not exist, this iterator will always be empty.

      • getCommitMetadataPaged

        java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> getCommitMetadataPaged(long minTimestamp,
                                                                                                long maxTimestamp,
                                                                                                int pageSize,
                                                                                                int pageIndex,
                                                                                                Order order)
        Returns an iterator over commit timestamps and associated metadata in a paged fashion.

        For example, calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(10000, 100, 0, Order.DESCENDING) will give the latest 100 commit timestamps that have occurred before timestamp 10000. Calling getCommitTimestampsPaged(123456, 200, 2, Order.DESCENDING will return 200 commit timestamps, skipping the 400 latest commit timestamps, which are smaller than 123456.

        The Entries returned by the iterator always have the commit timestamp as their first component and the metadata associated with this commit as their second component. The second component can be null if the commit was executed without providing metadata.

        Parameters:
        minTimestamp - The minimum timestamp to consider (inclusive). All lower timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        maxTimestamp - The highest timestamp to consider. All higher timestamps will be excluded from the pagination. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        pageSize - The size of the page, i.e. the maximum number of elements allowed to be contained in the resulting iterator. Must be greater than zero.
        pageIndex - The index of the page to retrieve. Must not be negative.
        order - The desired ordering for the commit timestamps
        Returns:
        An iterator that contains the commits for the requested page. Never null, may be empty. If the requested page does not exist, this iterator will always be empty.

      • getCommitMetadataAround

        java.util.List<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> getCommitMetadataAround(long timestamp,
                                                                                             int count)
        Returns pairs of commit timestamp and commit metadata which are "around" the given timestamp on the time axis.

        By default, this method will attempt to return the closest count/2 commits before and after the given timestamp. However, if there are not enough elements on either side, the other side will have more entries in the result list (e.g. if the request count is 10 and there are only two commits before the request timestamp, the list of commits after the request timestamp will have 8 entries instead of 5 to create a list of total length 10). In other words, the result list will always have as many entries as the request count, except when there are not as many commits on the store yet.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The request timestamp around which the commits should be centered. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve around the request timestamp. By default, the closest count/2 commits will be taken on both sides of the request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of pairs. The keys are commit timsetamps, the corresponding values are the commit metadata objects (which may be null). The list itself will never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order by timestamps.

      • getCommitMetadataBefore

        java.util.List<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> getCommitMetadataBefore(long timestamp,
                                                                                             int count)
        Returns pairs of commit timestamp and commit metadata which are strictly before the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling getCommitMetadataBefore(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the latest 10 commits (strictly) before the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve before the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of pairs. The keys are commit timsetamps, the corresponding values are the commit metadata objects (which may be null). The list itself will never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order by timestamps.

      • getCommitMetadataAfter

        java.util.List<java.util.Map.Entry<java.lang.Long,java.lang.Object>> getCommitMetadataAfter(long timestamp,
                                                                                            int count)
        Returns pairs of commit timestamp and commit metadata which are strictly after the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling getCommitMetadataAfter(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the oldest 10 commits (strictly) after the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve after the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of pairs. The keys are commit timsetamps, the corresponding values are the commit metadata objects (which may be null). The list itself will never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order by timestamps.

      • getCommitTimestampsAround

        java.util.List<java.lang.Long> getCommitTimestampsAround(long timestamp,
                                                         int count)
        Returns a list of commit timestamp which are "around" the given timestamp on the time axis.

        By default, this method will attempt to return the closest count/2 commits before and after the given timestamp. However, if there are not enough elements on either side, the other side will have more entries in the result list (e.g. if the request count is 10 and there are only two commits before the request timestamp, the list of commits after the request timestamp will have 8 entries instead of 5 to create a list of total length 10). In other words, the result list will always have as many entries as the request count, except when there are not as many commits on the store yet.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The request timestamp around which the commits should be centered. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve around the request timestamp. By default, the closest count/2 commits will be taken on both sides of the request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of timestamps. Never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order.

      • getCommitTimestampsBefore

        java.util.List<java.lang.Long> getCommitTimestampsBefore(long timestamp,
                                                         int count)
        Returns a list of commit timestamps which are strictly before the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling getCommitTimestampsBefore(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the latest 10 commits (strictly) before the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve before the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of timestamps. Never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order.

      • getCommitTimestampsAfter

        java.util.List<java.lang.Long> getCommitTimestampsAfter(long timestamp,
                                                        int count)
        Returns a list of commit timestamps which are strictly after the given timestamp on the time axis.

        For example, calling getCommitTimestampsAfter(long, int) with a timestamp and a count of 10, this method will return the oldest 10 commits (strictly) after the given request timestamp.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to investigate. Must not be negative.
        count - How many commits to retrieve after the given request timestamp. Must not be negative.
        Returns:
        A list of timestamps. Never be null, but may be empty (if there are no commits to report). The list is sorted in descending order.

      • countCommitTimestampsBetween

        int countCommitTimestampsBetween(long from,
                                 long to)
        Counts the number of commit timestamps between from (inclusive) and to (inclusive).

        If from is greater than to, this method will always return zero.

        Parameters:
        from - The minimum timestamp to include in the search (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        to - The maximum timestamp to include in the search (inclusive). Must not be negative. Must be less than or equal to the timestamp of this transaction.
        Returns:
        The number of commits that have occurred in the specified time range. May be zero, but never negative.

      • countCommitTimestamps

        int countCommitTimestamps()
        Counts the total number of commit timestamps in the store.
        Returns:
        The total number of commits in the store.

      • keyspaces

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> keyspaces()
        Returns the set of keyspace names currently used by the database on this branch.
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable set of keyspace names. May be empty, but never null.

      • find

        QueryBuilderStarter find()
        Returns a QueryBuilderStarter that allows for fluent design of queries.

        For usage examples, please check the individual methods of the QueryBuilder.

        Returns:
        A query builder.

      • find

        QueryBuilderFinalizer find(ChronoDBQuery query)
        Returns a QueryBuilderFinalizer that allows to execute the given query in various ways.

        Usage example: 

         // prepare a query
 ChronoDBQuery query = tx.find().inDefaultKeyspace().where("name").contains("Simon").toQuery();
 // this query can now be executed anywhere, even on another transaction!
 Iterator<Object> values = tx.find(query).getValues();
        Parameters:
        query - The prebuilt query to execute. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        A finalizer builder for the query.

      • put

        void put(java.lang.String key,
         java.lang.Object value)
        Sets the given key in the default keyspace to the given value.

        Usage example: 

         tx.put("Pi", 3.1415);
        Note that the get(String) method and its overloads (as well as find()) will not return the values assigned by this method, until commit() is called.
        Parameters:
        key - The key to modify. Must not be null.
        value - The new value to assign to the given key. Must not be null.

      • put

        void put(java.lang.String key,
         java.lang.Object value,
         PutOption... options)
        Sets the given key in the default keyspace to the given value.

        Usage example: 

         tx.put("Pi", 3.1415);
        Note that the get(String) method and its overloads (as well as find()) will not return the values assigned by this method, until commit() is called.
        Parameters:
        key - The key to modify. Must not be null.
        value - The new value to assign to the given key. Must not be null.
        options - The options to apply. May be empty.

      • put

        void put(java.lang.String keyspaceName,
         java.lang.String key,
         java.lang.Object value)
        Sets the given key in the given keyspace to the given value.

        If the keyspace with the given name does not yet exist, it will be created on-the-fly when this change is successfully committed.

        Usage example: 

         tx.put("MyKeyspace", "Pi", 3.1415);
        Note that the get(String) method and its overloads (as well as find()) will not return the values assigned by this method, until commit() is called.
        Parameters:
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to modify. Must not be null.
        key - The key to modify. Must not be null.
        value - The new value to assign to the given key. Must not be null.

      • put

        void put(java.lang.String keyspaceName,
         java.lang.String key,
         java.lang.Object value,
         PutOption... options)
        Sets the given key in the given keyspace to the given value.

        If the keyspace with the given name does not yet exist, it will be created on-the-fly when this change is successfully committed.

        Usage example: 

         tx.put("MyKeyspace", "Pi", 3.1415, PutOption.NONE);
        Note that the get(String) method and its overloads (as well as find()) will not return the values assigned by this method, until commit() is called.
        Parameters:
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to modify. Must not be null.
        key - The key to modify. Must not be null.
        value - The new value to assign to the given key. Must not be null.
        options - The options to apply. May be empty.

      • remove

        void remove(java.lang.String key)
        Removes the given key from the default keyspace.

        If the key given by the parameter does not exist in the keyspace, this method does nothing.

        Parameters:
        key - The key to remove. Must not be null.

      • remove

        void remove(java.lang.String keyspaceName,
            java.lang.String key)
        Removes the given key from the given keyspace.

        If the key given by the parameter does not exist in the keyspace, this method does nothing.

        Parameters:
        keyspaceName - The name of the keyspace to modify. Must not be null.
        key - The key to remove. Must not be null.

      • commit

        void commit()
     throws ChronoDBCommitException
        Commits the changes made to this transaction to the ChronoDB instance.

        This is an atomic, consistent, isolated and durable operation:

        • Either the entire change set is committed, or nothing is committed.
        • Changes to commit will be validated against certain constraints, which may cause the commit to fail to ensure database consistency.
        • No other transactions will see partial results of the commit.
        • Once this method returns successfully, the results of the commit are persisted and durable.

        After calling commit(), the transaction will receive a new timestamp, i.e. it will be forwarded in time to the time after the commit it just performed. Clients may continue to use transactions after calling commit() on them.

        Throws:
        ChronoDBCommitException - Thrown if a commit failed due to consistency violations.

      • commit

        void commit(java.lang.Object commitMetadata)
     throws ChronoDBCommitException
        Commits the changes made to this transaction to the ChronoDB instance.

        This is an atomic, consistent, isolated and durable operation:

        • Either the entire change set is committed, or nothing is committed.
        • Changes to commit will be validated against certain constraints, which may cause the commit to fail to ensure database consistency.
        • No other transactions will see partial results of the commit.
        • Once this method returns successfully, the results of the commit are persisted and durable.

        After calling commit(), the transaction will receive a new timestamp, i.e. it will be forwarded in time to the time after the commit it just performed. Clients may continue to use transactions after calling commit() on them.

        Parameters:
        commitMetadata - The metadata object to store alongside this commit. May be null. Will be serialized using the SerializationManager associated with this ChronoDB instance. Using primitives, collections of primitives or maps of primitives is recommended.
        Throws:
        ChronoDBCommitException - Thrown if a commit failed due to consistency violations.

      • commitIncremental

        void commitIncremental()
                throws ChronoDBCommitException
        Performs an incremental commit on this transaction.

        Incremental commits can be used to insert large batches of data into a ChronoDB instance. Their advantage over normal transactions is that they do not require the entire data to be contained in main memory before writing it to the storage backend.

        Recommended usage of this method: 

         ChronoDBTransaction tx = db.tx();
 try {
        // ... do some heavy work
        tx.commitIncremental();
        // ... more work...
        tx.commitIncremental();
        // ... more work...
        // ... and finally, accept the changes and make them visible to others
        tx.commit();
 } finally {
        // make absolutely sure that the incremental process is terminated in case of error
        tx.rollback();
 }

        Using an incremental commit implies all of the following facts:

        • Only one incremental commit process may be active on any given ChronoDB instance at any point in time. Attempting to have multiple incremental commit processes on the same ChronoDB instance will result in a ChronoDBCommitException on all processes, except for the first process.
        • While an incremental commit process is active, no regular commits on other transactions can be accepted.
        • Other transactions may continue to read data while an incremental commit process is active, but they cannot see the changes made by incremental commits.
        • An incremental commit process consists of several calls to commitIncremental(), and is terminated either by a full-fledged commit(), or by a rollback().
        • It is the responsibility of the caller to ensure that either commit() or rollback() are called after the initial commitIncremental() was called. Failure to do so will result in this ChronoDB instance no longer accepting any commits.
        • After the terminating commit(), the changes will be visible to other transactions, provided that they use an appropriate timestamp.
        • The timestamp of all changes in an incremental commit process is the timestamp of the first commitIncremental() invocation.
        • In contrast to regular transactions, several calls to commitIncremental() may modify the same data. Overwrites within the same incremental commit process are not tracked by the versioning system, and follow the "last writer wins" principle.
        • In the history of any given key, an incremental commit process appears as a single, large commit. In particular, it is not possible to select a point in time where only parts of the incremental commit process were applied.
        • A call to commitIncremental() does not update the TemporalKeyValueStore.getNow() timestamp. Only the terminating call to commit() updates this timestamp.
        • The timestamp of the transaction executing the incremental commit will be increased after each call to commitIncremental() in order to allow the transaction to read the data it has written in the incremental update. If the incremental commit process fails at any point, this timestamp will be reverted to the original timestamp of the transaction before the incremental commit process started.
        • Durability of the changes made by commitIncremental() can only be guaranteed by ChronoDB if the terminating call to commit() is successful. Any other changes may be lost in case of errors.
        • If the JVM process is terminated during an incremental commit process, and the terminating call to commit() has not yet been completed successfully, any data stored by that process will be lost and rolled back on the next startup.
        Throws:
        ChronoDBCommitException - Thrown if the commit fails. If this exception is thrown, the entire incremental commit process is aborted, and any changes to the data made by that process will be rolled back.

      • rollback

        void rollback()
        Performs a rollback on this transaction, clearing all changes made to it.

        This transaction may be used after calling rollback, in contrast to when calling commit().

      • getChangeSet

        java.util.Collection<ChangeSetEntry> getChangeSet()
        Returns the change set that contains the pending changes which will be stored upon calling commit().
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable view on the change set. May be empty, but never null.

      • getConfiguration

        ChronoDBTransaction.Configuration getConfiguration()
        Returns the configuration of this transaction.
        Returns:
        The transaction configuration. Never null.
